author: Stagmeister

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello All,

This is the problem with me being stymied in my current game: I start thinking about other stuff. To be fair, some of you are partially to blame because of your interesting builds in the OC!

What I'd like is a strength-based monk build (predominantly), with some bardic abilities (singing, mostly) and maybe some RDD if that adds to toughness (just had a thought - I have no idea what Purple Dragon Knight does - any merit?). Unarmed would be a preference, but I couId live with kamas. Had contemplated some druid, but I decided I'm too old to learn spell-chucking now.

I'm not intending to begin with the OC: maybe SoU ('cause I've never played it from L1), or another module (happy to take recommendations) I've never played before. I'll probably try to solo it, if poss, and I'm not bothered about race/gender/goodness (although I still can't get my head around playing evil, so I'd rather not do that), because Aribeth won't be an issue. I know from reading other builds you've posted that Dwarf is well-liked, but perhaps half-orc is a possibility? If so, I'll probably go as a bloke, because if I'm going to girl it up I want to be drop-dead-gorgeous, superficial git that I am.

This is not me just asking out of boredom: I've only played a 'pure' monk before (up to L28-ish), but have been inspired by some of Empyre's OC build - and Monsieur le Dagger's bard seems to be doing great things. So, this is a build I'd really like to take to L40.

Thanks in advance.

Stagmeister - aka Pain-in-the-posterior

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I hope your problem will be fixed soon Stagmeister. Now, before we go to the build part i would like to mention a couple of things if you would like to hear them,

a) Monks and Bards do not mix well, that is because they require an alighnment change (or several) and you are not guaranteed to have access to that. Now, you will see some builds that do have an alighnment change here but we usually try to not mix different things like that, exactly because we do not know how easy this will be for the player. Usually when we do that, it is for some build requests that specifically state that their persistent world allows for these changes.

b) You have to understand that the O.C/ SOU/ HoTU and Aribeth's Redemption are all Monty Haul's campaigns. They are all very high magic environments that forgive mistakes and simplified builds. The ECB builds on the other hand, are best suited for low-to-medium magic environments ( that is a generalization, it is not true for all of the builds) that you will have to build-up an advantage through your builds abilities and clever play-style. To give you an example of this, think of your character in Aribeth's Redemption module, he has access to some really powerful magic items like rings of improved evasion, belts of greater guiding light, amulets of greater health, helmets that grand you mind-effects immunitiy and an elven forge that will add haste as a property of your weapon to name a few. In other quality modules like Adam Miller's " Shadowlords, Dreamcatcher and Demon Campaigns " or Tiberius " Saleron's Gambit " you won't find anything like that, and the same is true for some of the best Persistend Worlds out there, whereas +5 items are considered to be top of the line.

Now, you will be asking yourself, "why the heck should i care for all these" ? The answer is simple, your RDD's acquired ability to be totally immune to fire means little in any module that you can just purchase a ring of elemental resistance, or the Rogue's " improved evasion " means nothing if you can have this as a property of your armour. Generally a good build will always be a good build even with those parameters in play simply because they also have other abilities that are useful, like RDD's immense +8 strength bonus, but the higher the magical environment is, the less the usefulness of a really good build will be.
Keeping this information in mind and your request, i would suggest you start playing some quality modules that are not high magic so you can enjoy the benefits of your builds all the more. This will add value and high replay-ability to the game, wondering what compination of classes you should try next.

Here is my suggestion if you want to try something different from what you play now, it is a self-installed complete campaign, just an *exe file that you click on it and you are done. I will advice you not to play as a Monk here however, a Fighter or Paladin or even Bard are better suited for this.

Adam Miller's campaign => http://neverwintervault.org/project/nwn ... -campaigns

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
@ Empyre,

What you listed was a tool for making builds, Stagmeister i think is interested in the mental process that's involved in the making of a build, a.k.a "tips".

@ Stagmeister,

What's involved in making a successful build is different from one person to the other but there is one point that almost everyone agrees. You need to know the rules, the better you know them, the more you can understand the synergies between the classes. The "NWN Wiki" is a powerful tool, consult it whenever you can. Then you need to have an clear "idea" for what you want to make, decide the class or classes you want inside your build and then start transfer them to "paper" and set the order of them. Once you have them set, start putting your feats inside, make sure everything is eligible for taking. Then after you finish the first draft of your build, look at it again and now see if you would change anything or if you can improve upon something. If so, then do it. If something is particularly difficult then take a break and come at it at a later time.

When you have the finished build in your hands (Hard Drive, Whatever) then post it here in this section of the forums and let us wail upon it. Chances are that your first build won't be very strong and it could take some improvements, but the next one you try will be better. Here is something critical, do not get disheartened if you made some mistakes, keep persisting and you will win. My advice would be to make a "pure" build first, whatever you are most comfortable with, then as you are getting more familiar with the process then start making more complicated builds. Do not frown upon the "pure" builds as some do, there is a huge difference between an average pure build and one that is well-made and if you look upon the "Yardstick Builds" thread you will discover some really "mean monsters" inside. Another critical thing is to get your hands "dirty" and start trying some ideas, how would you build Mazzy for example? She is a plain fighter or so it seems, but she is a Halfling and she is dual-wielding her tiny blades. You instantly know that, this means you will need at least 15 DEX in your build, set your stats accordingly and proceed. If you want her to do some serious damage then you need to take her STR high, as high as you can propably, for a Hin, make that your priority and move on. Then you start to formulate some ideas in your mind, what can i do with so many feats? Shall i make her an expert with a Bow as well (she is a master, in BG2)? Can i push there some saving boosters in the general feat levels? Then after you finish her build, look at it again and think. Maybe i should give her "blind fight" earlier or IKD in that matter, what should i put first so to make the build level more easily? And it goes on from there..

Whatever you decide man, i want you to know that we are here to help, that's all.

Best of luck with your first build(s) and i want you to know that it feels somewhat special when you play your very own build ;)

~ You point - I punch!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I would pick the robes with the highest AC I could find. It is better to not get hit than to absorb some damage. Besides, it would only take a +3 weapon to completely bypass +3 soak 10. Also, with a STR-based character, I would use the belt and gloves to boost STR rather than DEX.

Te only infinite fire ammo weapon I know of in HotU is a bow that you can buy in the Drow town in the Underdark, but only an Arcane Archer can use it. To be honest, I cheated by loadeing my character into the Pretty Good Char Creator between HotU and Sands of Fate, and made myself a bow with all the features that Risolvr would put on a melee weapon, except replacing 2d6 elemental damage with infinite fire arrows. If you don't want to do that, you will be better off with more than 1 stack of fire bolts (5 or 6 should do). In addition to quite a few green slimes, there are a few black puddings that also try to dissolve your weapon (I hope I remember correctly which ooze it was that did that).

You gear does transfer to Sands of Fate, unless you choose a skill level higher than Normal. At Hardcore or higher, you only keep what you have equipped. The module itself will warn you about that.

I usually do the undead quest, then the 2 islands, and then the beholders and mind flayers. There is also a quest to do in the Drow village itself, which will help in the big battle if you do it.
